In the 2nd paragraph of my previous comment, I meant "extension" where I said "plugin". Sorry for any confusion.

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Young: The provider networking code currently under review will require very little change to take advantage of this extension mechanism. First, I'll remove the modifications that were made to the router.py and views.py core files. Second, I'll add a Providernet.get_extended_attributes method that returns the dictionary describing its extended attribute(s). No change at all will be required to the processing of the provider attribute(s) in the plugins. Of course I'll remove the comments about needing an appropriate extension mechanism, and there will be changes in response to other comments in that review.

Gary: I agree a good example extension would cover all the properties that can be set on the attributes. This plugin is really currently intended just to achieve the unit test code coverage, and there is nothing different about how those properties are handled with extended attributes vs. core attributes. I do agree a better example will eventually be needed, along with updates to the wiki documentation on writing extensions and plugins. I believe these can be done later. Note that the provider network code will likely provide an example of using the validity checking (at least that the vlan_id is numeric)."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

And of course I meant "Yong" rather than "Young".'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Apologies for the delay on this review.
It it almost ok for me, meaning that although the code looks great I have some questions inline.

One thing we might want to add to this patch is some unit tests for covering the new bits of code in the extension manager. Looks like v2attributes.py goes in this direction, but that module is not used by any test module. Is there perhaps anything missing in this commit?'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This patch set is just a rebase due to conflicting changes to test_api_v2.py. No other changes were made.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (3 inline comments)

OK, the upcoming patch set will have the copying of RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP moved to the test_api_v2.ExtensionTestCase setUp/tearDown functions, will have the V2Views tests restored (except test_resource), and will have a comment clarifying how the v2attritutes extension is loaded in the ExtensionTestCase setUp function.

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (5 inline comments)

Salvatore, see my response to your comment in v2attributes.py. This is tested via the test_api_v2 unit tests.

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

See my in-line responses to all the comments. The main issue at this point is whether the current copying of the RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP global by router.py is acceptable, or if instead the test_api_v2.ExtensionTestCase's setup should make a copy and its teardown should restore the original state. The copy/restore is needed to ensure extended attributes added by one test case don't remain for further test cases.

I will rebase and publish a new patch set soon, so please let me know if the comments were not adequately addressed by the responses, and whether or not you think the copying should be moved."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-23 05:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Implements data-driven views and extended attributes.

The quantum/api/v2/views.py module is replaced by is_visible
properties in the RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP defined in
quantum/api/v2/attributes.py. Extensions are given the ability to add
extended attribute descriptions to this map during initialization,
allowing extended attributes to be implemented similarly to core
attributes in plugins.

Resolves bug 1023111.

Change-Id: Ic6e224d5d841b6a1d4d1c762d7306adaf91f7a2d

option must be an IP address, not a hostname.

thread:

Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/10102

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-21 07:56:04.000000000', 'message': 'Fix CoreFilter setting to avoid overallocation

From Jon Proulx (jproulx), who is still awaiting approval:

"Only schedule instances on hosts if there are sufficient CPU
cores available. If this filter is not set, the scheduler may
overprovision a host based on cores"

but in reality cpu_allocation_ratio must also be set with this
 filter. According to http://docs.openstack.org/essex/openstack-
compute/admin/content/compute-options-reference.html
 cpu_allocation_ratio defaults to 16.0 meaning cpu will be
 overprovisioned by 16:1 to get the behaviour described
 cpu_allocation_ratio must be set to 1.0

fixes bug 1027309

Change-Id: Ieea6c5ab13ce3514e508e4ad3799253d348b64d4
'}]
commit_message:
Fix CoreFilter setting to avoid overallocation

From Jon Proulx (jproulx), who is still awaiting approval:

"Only schedule instances on hosts if there are sufficient CPU
cores available. If this filter is not set, the scheduler may
overprovision a host based on cores"

but in reality cpu_allocation_ratio must also be set with this
 filter. According to http://docs.openstack.org/essex/openstack-
compute/admin/content/compute-options-reference.html
 cpu_allocation_ratio defaults to 16.0 meaning cpu will be
 overprovisioned by 16:1 to get the behaviour described
 cpu_allocation_ratio must be set to 1.0

fixes bug 1027309

Change-Id: Ieea6c5ab13ce3514e508e4ad3799253d348b64d4

chapter and puts it in a new chapter called volumes.

This is a pure refactoring, no content has been modified.

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-13 13:38:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I like the idea of failed rebuilds going back to the scheduler, but I'm concerned that with a catch-all excepetion handler and no attempt to undo actions that may have completed (such as network set-up and firewall updates) that this could leave a trail of wreckage behind.

Since this request is now going to go to multiple nodes, and the failure might be something specific to the request, that lack of clean-up will now affect multiple hosts.

I couldn't see anywhere that the resource counters reset if the build fails."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-07-13 14:44:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Phil,

With respect to the scheduler race blueprint, this is one of two patches I'm submitting to handle that. You might also take a gander at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9402/.  That one adds resource tracking logic to the compute host to more clearly identify the "starved host" kind of problem.  (It's tagged as WIP now because I wanted this patch to go through first.)

It is indeed doing a retry on all build errors.  I don't believe failure on a single node should necessarily fail the entire build automatically.  As far as cleanup goes, that kind of work seems like it should be the responsibility of the virt driver under the covers of the "spawn" method.  (This is how the xenapi driver handles it.)  At the ComputeManager level, I'm not sure how we could effectively "undo" all the possible failures.

One thing that could be done is to define a "retry-able build exception" versus an "abort build exception", though it's not immediately clear to me in what cases we'd want to just automatically fail the build. It seems simpler just to retry everything by default.  

This logic is, of course, configurable and retries can be disabled entirely.

Also, what "resource counters" are you referring to?'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-07-13 14:54:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

With the types of questions Phil brings up, I'd like at a minimum a DocImpact flag in the commit message. 

Ideally you'd look into a documentation plan for how to describe this to deployers. Please don't update devref/scheduler.rst as it is supposed to be deleted. 

See instead http://docs.openstack.org/essex/openstack-compute/admin/content/ch_scheduling.html, source found at https://github.com/openstack/openstack-manuals/blob/master/doc/src/docbkx/openstack-compute-admin/computescheduler.xml. 

Happy to work with you on a doc plan for this type of change."}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:07:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Hi Brian,

Take your point about cleanup in spawn being the responsibility of the virt driver - I was thinking more of the network but I'd missed exception handler around spawn that calls _deallocate_network.

I'd still like to be sure that exepction that triggers the rebuild is always logged, not clear to be that would always be as things stand. 

By "resource counters" I was referring to the "free_ram_mb" and friends in the compute_instance table, used by the scheduler filters.   I thought I understood how this worked in Essex in combiantion with the capacity_notifier, but I can't see where this went in Folsom.  I'll take a look at teh other change you mentioned.

One other thought - as notification is becomes a very useful way to track system activity, how about adding a specific notify events for "create.retried" and "create.failed" as peers of "create.end"'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:11:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:19:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Anne,

I added the DocImpact flag with some additional information on what's going on in this change set.  I didn't realize this capability was there until you mentioned it!

I'm not sure exactly what you mean by a documentation plan.  Do you want me to update one of those XML files in the github you linked?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/4640/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/544/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/5856/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/2055/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/2066/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/3722/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:33:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Still concerned that details of the specific exception are lost in some cases."}, {'account_id': 2835, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Phil,

Yes, the build exception is still being logged.  (No change there)  The idea of doing notifications for the build failures is interesting.  It seems like none of the current notifications are used to indicate failures (http://wiki.openstack.org/SystemUsageData) at this time, but I can definitely see that being useful in general.

About the counters, that functionality is rather confusing.  If you configure the capacity notifier, it collects some information about usage from notifications and feeds that back into the compute node model.  However, the scheduler basically ignores this information and re-calculates usage based off of instances assigned to each compute host in the database.  In other words, the information is mostly collected and then ignored.  (My other patch, the one in WIP status, endeavors to make the compute node model fully functional and usable by the scheduler)'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-07-13 15:51:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

Hi Brian,

So assume that _spawn runs fine, but for some reason another exception comes up from _update_access_ip or _notify_about_instance_usage - won't that go on to also trigger a reschedule ?

And if the reschedule fails, then I don't think the exception is logged. 

Maybe this sounds like a real corner case - but we've had some real struggles with systems in production tracking down issues from exceptions that  weren't logged.

It feels that as the intention is to only go into reschedule if something leading up to and including the spawn fails then the exception handling needs to more specific to just the scope of that block."}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-07-16 16:05:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (5 inline comments)

Questions mostly ...'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-07-16 16:26:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

I changed some of the exception handling around build failures to be more specific to spawn errors.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-16 17:08:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Adds generic retries for build failures.

Add a generic scheduler retry for build failures.  Failed
build requests get casted back to scheduler for retry until
success or the maximum number of attempts is reached. The
number of attempts to make is configurable or can be
simply set to 1 to disable retries altogether.

Partially implements blueprint: scheduler-resource-race

DocImpact:

Adds a new capability to filter scheduler to enable retries of
scheduling requests.

1) New flag: scheduler_max_attempts (int) - Number of attempts to make
to schedule an instance before giving up and settting the instance to
error.
2) New RetryFilter.  Avoids re-scheduling to the same host multiple
times. (nova.scheduler.filters.RetryFilter)

Change-Id: I1127caeed4418c75372a42ca7fafacb4f061ffe3

In the image management section, an example of how to boot a windows
image is given. Previously, virtio (a faster network card than
 default) was on the commandline, but not used in the VM

This change - taken from the bug report, and assumed to be OK rather
than tested - enables the nic.

fixes bug 1016663

Change-Id: I8b37f4eb268ca90a5b08238edec636a25973ec14
'}]
commit_message:
enable virtio NICs for windows image example

In the image management section, an example of how to boot a windows
image is given. Previously, virtio (a faster network card than
 default) was on the commandline, but not used in the VM

This change - taken from the bug report, and assumed to be OK rather
than tested - enables the nic.

fixes bug 1016663

Change-Id: I8b37f4eb268ca90a5b08238edec636a25973ec14

Your code clearly does what it states, but I don't understand the use case. It's entirely possible that's my own ignorance, so can you give an example of the use case?"}, {'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2012-07-21 07:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Several instances can share the same group and might need to be able to talk to one another, e.g. being able to SSH from one machine to another within the same group, or wackamoled load balancers who share the same group should be allowed to ping the other LBs and make sure they're still up.

There's also an explanation in the AWS docs: http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-network-security.html

"If you specify the security group itself as the source, each instance in the group will accept inbound traffic from fellow group members. For example, the default security group specifies itself as a source security group in its inbound security group rules. This is why members of the default security group allow inbound traffic from other members of the default security group."'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-07-22 09:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Fixes the syntax of nova options table

This was causing the build to fail - the problem here is
 that some items in the table have 3 columns - but there is only
two columns setup in the top. Merging to have two columns
fixes the problem

fixes bug 1027396

Change-Id: Ia3463a89c3a577e8acc7d779cd8110b3c05c141d

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Accepting values 0 and 1 for booleans definitely does make sense, and that does now work. But I'm wondering if values like "True", "true", "False", and "false" should also be accepted? The CLI displays booleans in responses as "True" and "False", so I would argue that either the CLI should translate these strings into 1 and 0, or the API should accept those strings. The JSON spec seems to prefer "true" and "false". I also wonder if the validation should replace the input data with a canonical representation so plugins don't have to worry about doing their own conversions. Anyway, it may be that separate validators are needed for boolean and integer types.

Also, if the conversion fails, the client now gets a 500 HTTP response. I think the validator needs to catch ValueError and return a descriptive string (from the ValueError?) so the base.py code translates this into the proper HTTP response status.

Finally, unit tests should be added/extended to make sure validation of booleans (and integers) accepts and rejects input values correctly.'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

Gary, 

I like your general approach to doing type conversion and replacing the value in the dict that will be passed to the plugin with the converted value. But I think it needs a bit more work. First, the conversion should apply to PUT requests as well as POST requests. Also, I think the type conversion needs to be done within the validator, since some aspects of validation need to be done before type conversion and others after. Note that absolutely anything converts successfully to a bool in python. The string "False" converts to True, which is not what most CLI users would expect. See the in-line comments as well.

Thanks,

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

See my in-line response to your comment. Both validation and conversion of values should work the same for an attribute whether that attribute is passed in a create or in an update operation (provided it is allowed in both). Of course defaulting only makes sense for create operations, so that's why it belongs in the allow_post section of the code where you currently have the conversion."}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

See my comments in the following CLI output:

(shell) net-create --tenant_id ten1 net1
Created a new network:
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
| Field          | Value                                |
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
| admin_state_up | 1.0                                  |
| id             | f2416a48-3ef0-4c0f-8679-29b073598a6b |
| name           | net1                                 |
| status         | ACTIVE                               |
| subnets        |                                      |
| tenant_id      | ten1                                 |
+----------------+--------------------------------------+

Why is a value of False for admin_state_up now displaying as "1.0"? Note that True still displays properly. Could the type conversion by causing this?


(shell) net-update f2416a48-3ef0-4c0f-8679-29b073598a6b --admin_state_up False
ERROR: cliff.app Invalid input for admin_state_up. Reason: False is not boolean.
(shell) net-update f2416a48-3ef0-4c0f-8679-29b073598a6b --admin_state_up 0
ERROR: cliff.app Invalid input for admin_state_up. Reason: 0 is not boolean.
(shell) net-update f2416a48-3ef0-4c0f-8679-29b073598a6b --admin_state_up "0"
ERROR: cliff.app Invalid input for admin_state_up. Reason: 0 is not boolean.
(shell) net-update f2416a48-3ef0-4c0f-8679-29b073598a6b --admin_state_up "True"
ERROR: cliff.app Invalid input for admin_state_up. Reason: True is not boolean.

In all of the above cases, I think the input should have been accepted. These are the PUT messages I've been talking about.



(shell) 
(shell) net-create --tenant_id ten1 net2 --admin_state_up False
Created a new network:
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
| Field          | Value                                |
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
| admin_state_up | False                                |
| id             | f0c85e04-b024-4ab3-825f-89824fc0de18 |
| name           | net2                                 |
| status         | ACTIVE                               |
| subnets        |                                      |
| tenant_id      | ten1                                 |
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
(shell) net-create --tenant_id ten1 net3 --admin_state_up 0
Created a new network:
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
| Field          | Value                                |
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
| admin_state_up | 0.0                                  |
| id             | 3971bb29-259e-4d5e-aa36-dce12bad233a |
| name           | net3                                 |
| status         | ACTIVE                               |
| subnets        |                                      |
| tenant_id      | ten1                                 |
+----------------+--------------------------------------+
(shell) 

These POST messages did accept the input for admin_state_up. But it doesn't seem the converted type is getting stored, because the displayed value differs ("False" vs. "1.0").

-Bob'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Hopefully the output below is formatter better than last time. I am still seeing two issues:

1) The validation/conversion still does not work the same for PUT as it does for POST. See the failures to update net1 below.

2) The converted value is still not getting stored/returned by the plugin. I still see "0", "1", "True", and "False" in the responses to the create for net2-net5 below, depending on the form of the input. I believe the response messages (and the data passed to the plugin and stored in the DB) should also be a real boolean True or False, and never an int or string.

-Bob


(shell) net-create --tenant_id ten1 net1

(shell)'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1689, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I agree with Aaron that we should consider having the client send the proper data type, but I'm not totally clear on what's considered best practice for RESTful JSON servers accepting boolean data. Also, I'm not sure our CLI will always know the correct type, especially for extended attributes. Anyway, this patch is definitely an improvement and resolves the bug, so I'm approving it."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

IMO, we should add _validate_boolean

Even if  'validate': {'type:values:int': [True, False]}}, works, it looks violating Rule of Least Surprise"}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks! Gary'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Tested and works. Though, I think it makes more sense to make the client send in a bool rather than a string (and only accept a bool). That said I don't really feel strongly either way about this. 

I filed a bug against the client for this: https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-quantumclient/+bug/1026818"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-22 00:13:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified

commit_message:
Enhance V2 validations to work better for integers and booleans

Fixes bug 1026598

The attributes are now able to cast a input value to a specific type.
At the moment boolean and int are supported.

Change-Id: I568a95bc60f91c3eeae03b305031502d50de9c44

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-09 04:52:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We should talk to Trey about this.  In general, our plan was to support creating VM NICs either by passing in a quantum network-uuid (with nova automatically creating a new port on the network) or a quantum port-uuid (in which case nova just uses that port). 

The idea is that we don't want people to have to pass all possible quantum port attributes (IPs, security groups, etc.) in through nova.  So instead, if they want something other than a "default" port, a tenant (or code acting on behalf of the tenant) would create a port with those settings and pass it to Nova.  

So I think ideally we'd change the request_networks extension to take port-id rather than individual attributes like IP-address.  This would keep the quantum code in nova really simple, which is ideal.  It would make thinks slightly more complicated if you're using the nova + quantum clients, but with Horizon, or with a joint openstack client, it could be a simple workflow.  Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-07-17 23:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Dan

I like the way passing port-id for each nic.
By this work, we can keep architecture simple on server side.
However Some consideration is needed for this.

1) Nova boot command
I don't want to create port for each server creation, so IMO, nova boot command should create each port.

2) Access Control model
Until now, quantum api is not needed to expose for user. However, we should expose quantum api itself for users.

Instead of using port-id, howabout just proxy json values to the quantum?
Something like this

networks:[
{
  "network_id": "98bd8391-199f-4440-824d-8659e4906786",
  "admin_state_up": True,
  "mac_address": "ca:fe:de:ad:be:ef",
  "fixed_ips": [ "10.0.0.2" ],
  "host_routes":  [ { "destination": "0.0.0.0/0", "nexthop" : "10.0.0.1" },
                           { "destination": "10.0.0.0/24", "nexthop": Null }],
},
{
  "network_id": "98bd8391-199f-4440-824d-8659e4906786",
  "admin_state_up": True,
  "mac_address": "ca:fe:de:ad:be:ef",
  "fixed_ips": [ "10.0.0.3" ],
  "host_routes":  [ { "destination": "0.0.0.0/0", "nexthop" : "10.0.0.1" },
                           { "destination": "10.0.0.0/24", "nexthop": Null }],
}
]'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-20 07:58:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Nachi,

Already you can use the boot command and pass no --nic options, in which case the VM will get a default set of NICs (currently, all networks associated with a project, but Trey has suggested changing it to a default network configured in nova).  

Also, you can use --nic with net-id=X if you know the network you want the port created on, but don't want to create the port yourself.

The only time you need to specify a port-id is if you want to customize the port.  The goal here is to avoid complicating the nova create server API call, and the nova boot command with a bunch of networking specific details.  Instead, if you need to customize, first create a port, then just pass that port to nova.  That is, rather than having nova accept all parameters that quantum accepts when creating a port and proxying the call to Quantum, just pass that information to quantum first, get a port-id, and pass the port-id to Nova.  This is just as easy in programmatic terms, and keep the APIs cleaner.  In terms of CLI, we don't want to add each attribute of a quantum port to the nova CLI.  Instead, use the quantum API to create the port, since it has the correct options, then get the resulting port-id and pass it to nova boot."}, {'account_id': 2031, 'date': '2012-07-20 13:59:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Dan

That's make sense. +1 for port id"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-07-20 17:38:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Hi Yong, having this supported will be very valuable.  

I have a few minor nits/questions inline, nothing major.  

I also think there is a potential issue in that booting a VM with an invalid IP address results in an internal error and puts the VM in ERROR state, but ideally it would actually cause the creation of the VM to fail.  This was the original goal of validate_networks(), which would result in an HTTP error if any of the net-ids were invalid.  This highlights another benefit of the approach where tenants can only pass in a net-id or a port-id, since it is easy to validate the ownership of nets/ports in validate_networks, and quantum takes are of validating the correctness of all other inputs directly.  What do you think?  Its certainly possible to validate an IP in validate_networks, but it just seems to add more complexity to nova for something that is already done in Quantum.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-07-20 19:12:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-07-21 23:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9295/ got in.'}]

Allows the creation of related objects during a workflow.
For example, this patch implements importing keypairs during
the launch instance workflow and allocating floating IP
addresses during the floating IP associate workflow.

This required several significant changes:

  * SelfHandlingForm should no long return a redirect.
    Instead, it should return either the object it
    created/acted on, or else a boolean such as True.

  * The ModalFormView now differentiates between GET

  * Due to the previous two items, SelfHandlingForm

In the process of these large changes there was a large

code and the existing SelfHandlingForm subclasses/ModalFormView
subclasses. Many small bugs were fixed along with the cleanup.

Implements blueprint inline-object-creation.

commit_message:
Inline object creation.

Allows the creation of related objects during a workflow.
For example, this patch implements importing keypairs during
the launch instance workflow and allocating floating IP
addresses during the floating IP associate workflow.

This required several significant changes:

  * SelfHandlingForm should no long return a redirect.
    Instead, it should return either the object it
    created/acted on, or else a boolean such as True.

  * The ModalFormView now differentiates between GET
    and POST.

  * Due to the previous two items, SelfHandlingForm
    was mostly gutted (no more maybe_handle, etc.).

  * Modals now operate via a "stack" where only the
    top modal is visible at any given time and closing
    one causes the next one to become visible.

In the process of these large changes there was a large
amount of general code cleanup, especially in the javascript
code and the existing SelfHandlingForm subclasses/ModalFormView
subclasses. Many small bugs were fixed along with the cleanup.

Implements blueprint inline-object-creation.

Fixes bug 994677.
Fixes bug 1025977.
Fixes bug 1027342.
Fixes bug 1025919.

Change-Id: I1808b34cbf6f813eaedf767a6364e815c0c5e969

Update instance fixed.

Change-Id: Iac5902a4817e3402553d6ea5c9047e2471893e90

more

Change-Id: I584efefd426dd172f12b951d8c1e553786f3ba47

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-19 09:51:35.000000000', 'message': "Sync jsonutils from openstack-common

This makes horizon work with recent versions of anyjson.

Changes from openstack-common:

    commit ce3071437d1871f77c4d8573cbe5f4ea8c817650
    Author: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
    Date:   Mon Jul 16 10:30:25 2012 -0400

        Use strtime() in to_primitive() for datetime objs.

        This patch updates jsonutils.to_primitive() to use timeutils.strtime()
        to convert a datimetime object to a string instead of just using str().
        This ensures that we can easily convert the string back to a datetime
        using timeutils.parse_strtime().

        Required for the nova blueprint no-db-messaging.

        Change-Id: I725b333695930e12e2832378102514326fec639c

    commit 4c9d439ef24f5afdd74aa9153aa8fc772051e6cb
    Author: Tim Daly Jr <timjr@yahoo-inc.com>
    Date:   Tue Jun 26 02:48:42 2012 +0000

        Add 'filedecoder' method to the jsonutils wrapper module.

        Fixes bug #1017765

        After version 3.3.2, the anyjson library will throw a KeyError if
        filedecoder isn't present.  The filedecoder is just like the decoder
        except it takes a file instead of a string, like json.load() instead
        of json.loads().

        Change-Id: I7bd012a7b4afa9b1ec987c3e6393cc922b5dadff

Change-Id: I912116d56e4e31ae93042929775c8d03dc4fa59e
"}, {'created': '2012-07-19 10:27:54.000000000', 'message': "Partial sync of jsonutils from openstack-common

This makes horizon work with recent versions of anyjson. Note that
there's another jsonutils change in openstack-common, but it requires
timeutils (which adds a dependency on the iso8601 module), so I skipped
it for now.

Changes from openstack-common:

    commit 4c9d439ef24f5afdd74aa9153aa8fc772051e6cb
    Author: Tim Daly Jr <timjr@yahoo-inc.com>
    Date:   Tue Jun 26 02:48:42 2012 +0000

        Add 'filedecoder' method to the jsonutils wrapper module.

        Fixes bug #1017765

        After version 3.3.2, the anyjson library will throw a KeyError if
        filedecoder isn't present.  The filedecoder is just like the decoder
        except it takes a file instead of a string, like json.load() instead
        of json.loads().

        Change-Id: I7bd012a7b4afa9b1ec987c3e6393cc922b5dadff

Change-Id: I912116d56e4e31ae93042929775c8d03dc4fa59e
"}]
commit_message:
Partial sync of jsonutils from openstack-common

This makes horizon work with recent versions of anyjson. Note that
there's another jsonutils change in openstack-common, but it requires
timeutils (which adds a dependency on the iso8601 module), so I skipped
it for now.

Changes from openstack-common:

    commit 4c9d439ef24f5afdd74aa9153aa8fc772051e6cb
    Author: Tim Daly Jr <timjr@yahoo-inc.com>
    Date:   Tue Jun 26 02:48:42 2012 +0000

        Add 'filedecoder' method to the jsonutils wrapper module.

        Fixes bug #1017765

        After version 3.3.2, the anyjson library will throw a KeyError if
        filedecoder isn't present.  The filedecoder is just like the decoder
        except it takes a file instead of a string, like json.load() instead
        of json.loads().

        Change-Id: I7bd012a7b4afa9b1ec987c3e6393cc922b5dadff

Change-Id: I912116d56e4e31ae93042929775c8d03dc4fa59e

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary use of with_lockmode

Using with_lockmode outside of a transaction is useless. It's also
unnecessary when code won't ever make any updates to the records.

Change-Id: Ib58b035cc5803e49654570b451ad381bebdd300c

In _get_flavor_refs, don't retrieve inactive flavors.  Fixes bug 1026210.

Instruct guests to ensure at boot, that the correct
SELinux context is set for /root/.ssh/.
This will cater for keys injected by nova from hosts
without SELinux (enabled) or using libguestfs which
currently doesn't support setting extended attributes.

commit_message:
set correct SELinux context for injected ssh keys

Instruct guests to ensure at boot, that the correct
SELinux context is set for /root/.ssh/.
This will cater for keys injected by nova from hosts
without SELinux (enabled) or using libguestfs which
currently doesn't support setting extended attributes.

Suggested-by: David Naori <dnaori@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ibf3869e3ee477e91623e0c030838c1ec8a6128a6

commit_message:
Add Cinder to ROOTWRAP_SUDOERS

 * Perform operations in lib/cinder
 * Use specific cidner-rootwrap file
 * Add root_helper to cinder.conf

This patches uses the much more useful UUID.

Change-Id: I6a9dd712dbac1d1b1aaba65da2b7c399b606e934

commit_message:
Improve VDI chain logging.

Currently we're logging the parent's OpaqueRef which is rather useless.
This patches uses the much more useful UUID.

Some small cleanups are included as well.

Change-Id: I6a9dd712dbac1d1b1aaba65da2b7c399b606e934

commit_message:
Support requested_networks with quantum v2.

Allow Quantum to attach instance only to selected networks, which can
be specified, for instance, via the --nic option on the nova CLI.

Fixes bug 1019899

Change-Id: I099056387edea9e3646cd4e329c76b674e03baa2

'Command failed.' message when there is no network defined or
all networks have been deleted or even when a network gets
deleted, then a new network gets created. In all these cases,
the command produces the 'Command failed.' error message which
does not really tell what went wrong. This fix will produce
'No fixed IP found' in these conditions.

Change-Id: I3c2e9bf3fa3c748e680c1df27d243a648ed47cf5

commit_message:
Fixes nova-manage fixed list with deleted networks

The fix addresses the bug reported in bug 1025827
currently command 'nova-manage fixed list' will return
'Command failed.' message when there is no network defined or
all networks have been deleted or even when a network gets
deleted, then a new network gets created. In all these cases,
the command produces the 'Command failed.' error message which
does not really tell what went wrong. This fix will produce
'No fixed IP found' in these conditions.
changes made for globalization.
changes made for based on the comments for patchset 7.

Change-Id: I3c2e9bf3fa3c748e680c1df27d243a648ed47cf5

commit_message:
Move libvirt disk config setup out of main get_guest_config method

The get_guest_config method in the libvirt driver is getting
quite large and complicated, particularly wrt disk config.
Moving the disk config setup out into a separate method,
get_guest_storage_method, eases understanding of the code

Change-Id: Ibbfbb88cafa45c98792e6732da726ab4afe4ca00
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Refactor libvirt imagebackend module to reduce code duplication

Currently each subclass of the Image class in imagebackend,
repeats the impl of the 'libvirt_info' method. These methods
are almost identical, only varying on two per-class settings.
By providing the driver_format and source_type to the Image
class constructor, it is possible to get to a single impl
of the 'libvirt_info' method.

Change-Id: I0807eed7f03aedf4980eedeb70195076ed5f4710
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move more libvirt disk setup into the imagebackend module

Move the setup of target bus and target dev out of the libvirt
driver and into the imagebackend module to reduce code duplication

Change-Id: I6796c125af769236f93341361ee07c8319817f7f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Don't hardcode use of 'virtio' for root disk in libvirt driver

The libvirt driver is mistakenly using 'virtio' for the root
disk, instead of the hypervisor specific disk bus.

Change-Id: I742184b08a3ecd428af21ae5beb059bdbf38a9cd
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Ensure to use 'hdN' for IDE disk device in libvirt driver

When configuring the root disk for an image which is tagged as
an ISO, the libvirt driver sets the bus=ide, but still uses
the normal root device name, eg dev=vda. It must instead
use dev=hda for the IDE bus

Change-Id: If0a4c50043d6e4d9e54a5dcbdc05effbb72eced6
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-07-20 12:02:22.000000000', 'message': "Get rid of pointless 'suffix' parameter in libvirt imagebackend

The libvirt 'imagebackend' module has various methods which take
a 'name' and 'suffix' argument. They are never used in isolation,
however, so passing them separately has no benefit. Indeed all
but one caller passes a name which already has a suffix appended
The suffix argument can thus trivially be removed completely.

Change-Id: I2ee0f3d104a2eb5139fc85c2db68e36255b82dad
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2012-07-20 13:02:48.000000000', 'message': "Get rid of pointless 'suffix' parameter in libvirt imagebackend

The libvirt 'imagebackend' module has various methods which take
a 'name' and 'suffix' argument. They are never used in isolation,
however, so passing them separately has no benefit. Indeed all
but one caller passes a name which already has a suffix appended
The suffix argument can thus trivially be removed completely.

Change-Id: I2ee0f3d104a2eb5139fc85c2db68e36255b82dad
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Get rid of pointless 'suffix' parameter in libvirt imagebackend

The libvirt 'imagebackend' module has various methods which take
a 'name' and 'suffix' argument. They are never used in isolation,
however, so passing them separately has no benefit. Indeed all
but one caller passes a name which already has a suffix appended
The suffix argument can thus trivially be removed completely.

Change-Id: I2ee0f3d104a2eb5139fc85c2db68e36255b82dad
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move setup of libvirt disk cachemode into imagebackend module

There is alot of repeated code setting the disk cache mode.
Move this into the imagebackend module so that it can be
done in one place

Change-Id: I7bff6b0b2e7e40a5aef3126634ca814082f8cf4f
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

Looks great. Did you investigate trying to create the backing file on the dest instead of merging it the way we do with live migration? When I looked at it before I wasn't sure what would happen if you tried to force an image with a backing file to use a backing file of a different size. For a resize from 10G to 20G my thought was download the 20G backing file and use qemu-image rebase -u to rebase onto the new file. Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-07-18 23:06:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Vish -- I like the idea of trying to rebase these images. I think an admin would find it surprising if his local disk use spiked because he migrated instances to new compute nodes. It sounds a bit like getting the backing files into the right place is an early step to towards the image pre-fetching we've talked about as well -- if the compute node had a RPC call to pre-fetch a base image, then this code could just execute that before migrating, and the image pre-fetch tool could just use the same RPC.

I'm interested in other people's thoughts on this."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-07-18 23:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Although I should say, I think we should take this code, and then revisit it when pre-fetch is done.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-07-19 09:23:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Vish I had thought about that, but considered it for later.
This patch is more about efficient transfer of the existing images, and so less invasive.

This patch might also be considered appropriate for stable,
whereas a more invasive one might not?'}, {'account_id': 1904, 'date': '2012-07-19 10:21:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-17 22:40:36.000000000', 'message': 'improve efficiency of qcow2 image migration

This reduces time to transfer a 10G qcow2 image,
over GigE, from about 7 minutes to about 30 seconds.

There are multiple inefficiencies in the existing process.
Taking an example of a 10G qcow2 image, the process is:

  qcow2 -> raw -> read -> send -> write -> qcow2

qcow2 to raw takes 20s,
transfer of the resultant 10G is another 4m9s, and
conversion back to qcow takes 2m33s.
I.E. a total of about 7 minutes.

Now you could speed up the transfer at least,
by using `rsync -Sz` rather than `scp`.
That would compress runs of zeros
and create sparse destination files.
That knocks about 30s off the transfer time,
while greatly reducing the network traffic,
and space usage at the destination. This gain
is limited though by rsync inefficiently reading
all the holes at the source:
https://bugzilla.samba.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8918

So instead we try to avoid the initial qcow2 to raw
conversion completely, which results in the whole
process completing in about 30s, in the common
case where no conversion to raw is done on the destination.

Note this will also improve the situation when
resizing/migrating within the same host as
needles conversions are avoided in that case too.

Thanks to David Naori <dnaori@redhat.com> for testing and ideas.

Change-Id: I9e87f912ef2717221c244241cda2f1027a4ca66a

commit_message:
improve efficiency of image transfer during migration

This reduces time to transfer a qcow2 image
with a virtual size of 10G, over GigE,
from about 7 minutes to about 30 seconds.

There are multiple inefficiencies in the existing process.
Taking an example of a qcow2 image with 10G virtual size,
the process was:

  qcow2 -> raw -> read -> send -> write -> qcow2

qcow2 to raw takes 20s,
transfer of the resultant 10G is another 4m9s, and
conversion back to qcow takes 2m33s.
I.E. a total of about 7 minutes.

So instead we try to avoid the initial qcow2 to raw
conversion completely, which results in the whole
process completing in about 30s, in the common
case where no conversion to raw is done on the destination.

We also optimize the case where the source qcow2
image doesn't have a backing file, and then directly
copy the source image without merging a backing file.

Note this will also improve the situation when
resizing/migrating within the same host as
needles conversions are avoided in that case too.

We also optimize the case where raw images are being used
by trying to use `rsync -Sz` rather than `scp`.
That compresses runs of zeros and create sparse destination files.
Testing a 10G raw image showed a saving of 30s in transfer time.
Also the network was greatly reduced (corresponding to holes
in the source), as was space usage at the destination.
This gain is limited though by rsync inefficiently reading
all the holes at the source:
https://bugzilla.samba.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8918

Thanks to David Naori <dnaori@redhat.com> for testing and ideas.

Change-Id: I9e87f912ef2717221c244241cda2f1027a4ca66a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-19 14:49:39.000000000', 'message': 'Fix cloudpipe keypair creation. Add pipelib tests

Commit ec0a65d81fd11d26be77b45827a4dd7c77711675 introduced a new
internal key pair API, removing the _gen_key() method from the EC2 API.
pipelib.py used this method so as to generate the keypair of the
cloudpipe instance.

This commit also adds unittests for pipelib.py, thus fixes bug 828588

Change-Id: I0884289bac01ac5109dde4bdee5af55e7bfd5aa2
'}]
commit_message:
Fix cloudpipe keypair creation. Add pipelib tests

Commit ec0a65d81fd11d26be77b45827a4dd7c77711675 introduced a new
internal key pair API, removing the _gen_key() method from the EC2 API.
pipelib.py used this method so as to generate the keypair of the
cloudpipe instance.

This commit also adds unittests for pipelib.py, thus fixes bug 828588

Change-Id: I0884289bac01ac5109dde4bdee5af55e7bfd5aa2

commit_message:
Ensure VHDs in staging area are sequenced properly.

This adds a check to raise a sensible error if the VHDs in the staging
area are not sequence numbered properly, meaning 0 to n-1 with no gaps.

The previous error was an UnboundLookupError which made it difficult to
pinpoint the root cause.

Change-Id: I6b9e4f854c271bf73711480568be384ba883775d

commit_message:
Ensure 413 response for security group over-quota

Fixes LP 1021748

Instead of raising the relevant webob.exc exception directly,
we now follow the usual pattern of mapping in the FaultWrapper
middleware from an internal exception type to the corresponding
HTTP error.

Change-Id: Ifb43685e4f9b0b5bd53e74747d1f87aa5e119fb5

[{'created': '2012-07-19 15:33:58.000000000', 'message': 'Allow NoMoreFloatingIps to bubble up to FaultWrapper

Fixes LP 1026167.

The fix for LP 1021721 caught the wrong exception in order to
address floating IP quota over-run. NoMoreFloatingIps is raised
when the floating range is exhausted, whereas FloatingIpLimitExceeded
is raised on over-quota.

Also the HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge exception raised is mapped
to 500 Server Error due to the required retry-after header being
left unset.

We now allow the NoMoreFloatingIps to bubble up to the FaultWrapper
middleware, where its mapped to a 404 status due to it extending
the NotFound exception.

Change-Id: Id35c487113059ec3053f2f9e9e7eca24854ac02c

commit_message:
Allow NoMoreFloatingIps to bubble up to FaultWrapper

Fixes LP 1026167.

The fix for LP 1021721 caught the wrong exception in order to
address floating IP quota over-run. NoMoreFloatingIps is raised
when the floating range is exhausted, whereas FloatingIpLimitExceeded
is raised on over-quota.

Also the HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge exception raised is mapped
to 500 Server Error due to the required retry-after header being
left unset.

We now allow the NoMoreFloatingIps to bubble up to the FaultWrapper
middleware, where its mapped to a 404 status due to it extending
the NotFound exception.

Change-Id: Id35c487113059ec3053f2f9e9e7eca24854ac02c

"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-07-05 14:16:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Couple of questions:

Like you point out: If we make this change instances will be killed (as much as possible) however some files may be left behind in the instances directory. This seems like it could potentially bad thing if since end users won't see the log ERROR message indicating that their instance was deleted but some files remain on disk.

Is there anything we can do w/ rootwrap (chowning the files for example) that would allow nova to better cleanup the instances directory in this case?

If not perhaps we need some sort of periodic service that  logs to Nova's compute.log when instances files from an undeleted instance exists? This would hopefully alert the deployer that some background cleanup tasks were needed."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-07-05 15:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> This seems like it could potentially bad thing if since end > users won't see the log ERROR message indicating that their > instance was deleted but some files remain on disk.

Of course the end user can't find any details about "ERROR", and in this case there's nothing they could do about it, even if they could find details. As a end user, my expectation would be that 'delete' should always work no matter what went wrong server side, and its upto admins to deal with any left over problems.

AFAICT, there's no commands/APIs for admins to discover the root causes either though.

I'm rather loathe to run either a recursive chmod, or rm -rf  via rootwrap, in case the user managed to arrange to get their system into a wierd state where a symlink in the container root has lots of ../../../  causing use to chmod or rm -rf the entire host root filesystem.'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-07-05 15:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-07-05 15:49:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

BTW, the scenario in which I was hitting this problem was related to this bug:

   https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9361/

Basically guestmount was failing to mount the container's image on the host. This error was caught and ignored, so Nova went on to create the container anyway, pointing at the directory where the image /should/ have been mounted. Libvirt thus created a bunch of sub dirs in that as root, before ultimately failing because the root filesystem was empty.

So if the above bug was fixed, we would never have got these root-owned directories created by libvirt and thus deletion would in fact have worked fine."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-05 16:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
Don't let failure to delete filesystem block deletion of instances in libvirt

During cleanup of instances, the libvirt driver tries to delete all
files under the /var/lib/nova/instances/$INSTANCENAME directory. If
Nova is running non-root, it is entirely possible for this to fail.
If this happens an OSError is raised and the result is an unkillable
instance. By catching and logging any OSError raised, we can ensure
that the instances are cleaned up as much as possible and not left
with unkillable instances.

Change-Id: I204b087c610396d917e94a6e35dd2f5e1c26704e
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

there is no network defined or networks get deleted. This fix combined
with fixes to bug 1025827 will fix both command problem.
also change the print out message so that it can be translated.
code structure changes according to the suggestion from comments.

Change-Id: Id9a1a10217aac971cbbba9db5829c8478892db1a
"}]
commit_message:
fixes for nova-manage network list  if network has been deleted

this fix addresses the  bug #1021810
Currently command 'nova-manage network list' or
'nova-manage fixed list'  will return 'Command failed.' message when
there is no network defined or networks get deleted. This fix combined
with fixes to bug 1025827 will fix both command problem.
also change the print out message so that it can be translated.
code structure changes according to the suggestion from comments.

Change-Id: Id9a1a10217aac971cbbba9db5829c8478892db1a

I had thought we were supposed to sync common changes separate from the code that used them?'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-07-17 19:56:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

A while ago I proposed best practices that included this item:

"""

 V.     Changes to openstack-common.conf are a special case.
     A. Patches with openstack-common.conf changes should include the relevant merge-from-common changes.
     B. Such patches should /not/ include any other merge-from-common changes.
     C. Such patches should not only include the common merges, but should also include whatever code changes make use of the new merge.
     D. Such patches require the same justification and scrutiny as any other standard project patch.

"""

This item got support from Russell.  IIRC, no one else responded to it at all.  So, I'm at least following my own guidelines :)'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-07-17 20:44:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-07-18 21:54:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

sean: i think it is fine to do it at once in this case since the plugins code isn't used yet. Otherwise we are bringing in a bunch of unused code. Do you think it would be easier to review in two chunks?"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-07-19 20:56:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

It was just from a bisect point of view after previous conversations on the list. I'm ok either way, so +1 from me. We should have a consistent statement on whether openstack-common should come in together or separate from changes that use it."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-07-20 18:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Tidy up handling of exceptions in floating_ip_dns

Removes translation of NotAuthorized which is already handled at a
higher level. Also makes delete methods more typical, switches http
status code on success to 202 rather than 200, includes details when
handling NotFound and adds test coverage.

Change-Id: Id59e397891b80b45ea38e42654a6f7f9859379f8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-18 19:59:11.000000000', 'message': 'Make snapshot work for stopped VMs.

Fix bug 1023682. Currently VM state is updated to ACTIVE no matter
what during snapshot. But VM should remain STOPPED if a snapshot
is taken on a stopped VM, i.e. remain unchanged.

VM state should not be changed during snapshot.

Change-Id: I5578e6064e23a8ff6f4019116b5bcdd12529360c
'}]
commit_message:
Make snapshot work for stopped VMs.

Fix bug 1023682. Currently VM state is updated to ACTIVE no matter
what during snapshot. But VM should remain STOPPED if a snapshot
is taken on a stopped VM, i.e. remain unchanged.

VM state should not be changed during snapshot.

Change-Id: I5578e6064e23a8ff6f4019116b5bcdd12529360c

commit_message:
Split ComputeFilter up.

Pull out compute capabilities to instance_type extra_specs into its own filter.
ComputeFilter now only passes active compute nodes.

Change-Id: If9b81bdd7b24faa8a27915a9e5de3e651f6ed0d0

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-14 06:58:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Restored

still wanted'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-07-16 20:16:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Help me understand why we need to force this...we already set the table type to innodb which is also mentioned as resolving the bug.'}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-17 06:30:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dean: without this, I get the following excepting while doing "nova-manage db sync":

(OperationalError) (1071, 'Specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes') '\nCREATE TABLE dns_domains (\n\tcreated_at DATETIME, \n\tupdated_at DATETIME, \n\tdeleted_at DATETIME, \n\tdeleted BOOL, \n\tdomain VARCHAR(512) NOT NULL, \n\tscope VARCHAR(255), \n\tavailability_zone VARCHAR(255), \n\tproject_id VARCHAR(255), \n\tPRIMARY KEY (domain), \n\tCHECK (deleted IN (0, 1)), \n\tFOREIGN KEY(project_id) REFERENCES projects (id)\n)ENGINE=InnoDB\n\n' ()'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-07-17 17:35:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

What is your platform, MySQL version, etc?  Vish says this all should have been fixed a while back, it's one reason we force InnoDB."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-18 08:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is with my openSUSE port of devstack on openSUSE 12.2 beta 2 (up-to-date as of June), and mysql 5.5.25.

I tried on Fedora, and it doesn't need this indeed.

After investigation, it turns out that Fedora creates databases with the utf8 character set by default, while openSUSE creates them with utf8 by default. Just create a database and do a "show variables like 'character%';" query to check that.

And looking at the code of nova, it really expects utf8 by default and then alters the database to utf8 at some point: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/082_essex.py#L971

See https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/082_essex.py#L270 for an explanation of why utf8 isn't used by default for the database.

So short summary: I really think the patch is correct :-)'}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-18 08:27:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I clicked "publish" too fast, sorry. Arguably, the commit message is a bit wrong, since it should probably mention nova wants utf8 instead. I can update the patch if there's agreement that the patch is fine.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-07-18 16:51:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

OK, I'm convinced.  Since this is really about Nova's assumption about default character set the commit message and comment in the code should reflect that."}, {'account_id': 4460, 'date': '2012-07-19 12:22:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-19 12:33:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/4197/testReport : SUCCESS

too long" error.

Change-Id: I81e6ed476e8a310fe01809e9afcc2c8d5360e9df
'}, {'created': '2012-07-19 12:22:51.000000000', 'message': 'Use latin1 character set when creating the nova database

Nova expects the latin1 character set to be used in its database by
default and then alters the database to utf8 when upgrading the
database (in 082_essex.py).

Nova works this way to work around bug 829209 ("Specified key was too

Change-Id: I81e6ed476e8a310fe01809e9afcc2c8d5360e9df
'}]
commit_message:
Use latin1 character set when creating the nova database

Nova expects the latin1 character set to be used in its database by
default and then alters the database to utf8 when upgrading the
database (in 082_essex.py).

Nova works this way to work around bug 829209 ("Specified key was too
long" errors) that will be hit with the dns_domains table.

Change-Id: I81e6ed476e8a310fe01809e9afcc2c8d5360e9df

commit_message:
EC2 DescribeImages reports correct rootDeviceType

Fixes LP 1024354

A root device type of instance-store was incorrectly reported for
boot-from-volume images (i.e. the analogue of EBS-backed AMIs).

When comparing the block device mapping device name with the root
device name, we now tolerate a missing leading '/dev/' path.

Change-Id: I1d3bda780deee52f5d41e3af041aba7e6305dfde

commit_message:
Fix venv wrapper to clean *.pyc.

Bug: 1021392

With this fix the commands executed within virtual environment,
including find command, are executed successfully.

* tools/with_venv.sh
  Enclose command to execute in virtual environment within quotes.

Change-Id: I886d70097090578e83adc20318600d16cc5ebead

Change-Id: I1eb9e6289a8171d6fc93a49b327df474b1e2e503
'}]
commit_message:
Improved VM detection for bandwidth polling (XAPI)

XenAPI bandwidth polling would fail or be unreliable if there
was any other virtual machines on the same node (such as the nova
compute node).  This uses the nova_uuid which is much more
reliable to be there.  Fixes LP Bug #918383

Change-Id: I1eb9e6289a8171d6fc93a49b327df474b1e2e503

commit_message:
Allow wget to handle Non-English output

The stack.sh has a loop to wait for keystone to start. But the output of wget tool has been globalized
which means it won't return the English word 'refused' on Non-English environment even the keystone is
not up. So the script will assume the keystone has been started and continue. The command of keystone
tenant-create always failed immediately after skipping this loop since it require keystone to be started
to authenticate. That's why you can see authentication error in the log because the tenant information
was not correctly set up.

Fix bug 1019942

Change-Id: Icc2bd9551e235173683e3677880c2641faee62a9

commit_message:
Move swift_auth middleware from keystone to swift.

- Rename it to keystoneauth for consistenties.
- Implements blueprint keystone-middleware.

Change-Id: I208fecdf3ee991694b4239f065032324d297fd35

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-05 13:53:50.000000000', 'message': 'Forbid substrings based on a regexp in name_filter middleware

In comments from https://review.openstack.org/8798 it was raised that it
might make sense to forbid some substrings in the name_filter
middleware.

There is now a new forbidden_regexp option for the name_filter
middleware to specify which substrings to forbid. The default is
"/\./|/\.\./|/\.$|/\.\.$" (or in a non-regexp language: the /./ and /../
substrings as well as strings ending with /. or /..).

This can be useful for extra paranoia to avoid directory traversals
(bug 1005908), or for more general filtering.

Change-Id: I39bf2de45b9dc7d3ca4d350d24b3f2276e958a62
DocImpact: new forbidden_regexp option for the name_filter middleware
'}, {'created': '2012-07-05 14:07:49.000000000', 'message': 'Forbid substrings based on a regexp in name_filter middleware

commit_message:
Forbid substrings based on a regexp in name_filter middleware

In comments from https://review.openstack.org/8798 it was raised that it
might make sense to forbid some substrings in the name_filter
middleware.

There is now a new forbidden_regexp option for the name_filter
middleware to specify which substrings to forbid. The default is
"/\./|/\.\./|/\.$|/\.\.$" (or in a non-regexp language: the /./ and /../
substrings as well as strings ending with /. or /..).

This can be useful for extra paranoia to avoid directory traversals
(bug 1005908), or for more general filtering.

Change-Id: I39bf2de45b9dc7d3ca4d350d24b3f2276e958a62
DocImpact: new forbidden_regexp option for the name_filter middleware

This would provide all the functionality listed here with minimal fuss and also addresses several of the concerns that Gary mentioned he has (that I'm echo'ing)"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-20 17:28:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I have a problem with this feature. By default each tenant is limited to X creations.
If the user wishes to update this he/she needs to restart the quantum service.
I understand that you wrote that the plugin can be updated to support a limitation per tenant. 
I have a number of questions:
1. Why is the feature not disabled by default?
2. Why not provide an API that enables the user to create a quota per tenant?
3. Why would keystone not implement this? That may be the most natural place for this to be done.
4. With the current implementation how can one limit tenant X to 10 networks and tenant Y to 30 networks and tenant Z to have unlimited networks?'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-07-20 17:28:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for addressing the questions. As mentioned in the answers the future developments with the quotas per tenants will address the main concerns that I have.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-07-20 17:28:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

hi Matt,
I don't think rate-limiting is the same as quota. All of the openstack projects have quota and rate-limiting features.

we will separate BP for rate-limiting."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-07-20 17:28:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

hi Gary:
1. Why is the feature not disabled by default?

Why should be disabled? nova's quota for each tenant is enabled by default as far as I know.

2. Why not provide an API that enables the user to create a quota per tenant?

I have to do this feature step by step. you can see my work itmes in my blueprint. I want to keep one change small so that it is easy to review.

3. Why would keystone not implement this? That may be the most natural place for this to be done.

All the quota is implemented in each project so far. It is not practical for keystone to have it now. 

4. With the current implementation how can one limit tenant X to 10 networks and tenant Y to 30 networks and tenant Z to have unlimited networks?

Please see my worktiems in BP."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-07-20 17:28:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (6 inline comments)

Add quota features into quantum.
Blueprint quantum-api-quotas

We support quota check for creating network, subnet and port.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-09 21:28:05.000000000', 'message': 'Provide stores access to the request context.

Adds a set_context function for the Store class which can be used
to provide an instantiated store access to the RequestContext.

Includes the following changes:

* Updates common store helper methods to call set_context on each
  store as it is retrieved from the list of know stores.

* Implement custom set_context call on the swift store.

* Updates Glance scrubber to create a real context from credentials.

The motivation for this change is that we will need access to the
service catalog and token for the Swift multi-tenant backend.

Partially implements blueprint: swift-tenant-specific-storage

Change-Id: I3def2b7c4085a36dd6c0961e762783ebaf7ffa74

commit_message:
Provide stores access to the request context.

Adds context to the constructor for the Store class. This can be used
to provide Store's access to the RequestContext.

Includes the following changes:

* Updates common store helper methods to create new instance of
  Store objects for each request.

* Updates Glance scrubber to create a real context from credentials.

The motivation for this change is that we will need access to the
service catalog and token for the Swift multi-tenant backend.

Partially implements blueprint: swift-tenant-specific-storage

Change-Id: I3def2b7c4085a36dd6c0961e762783ebaf7ffa74

all resources default to delete/create on update.

1. As this stands, the DB replicators will reload their rings on every loop iteration in run_forever(), while the object replicators will only do it every $ring_check_interval seconds. I don't think this discrepancy is desirable. Personally, I'd resolve it in favor of always checking.

If we're going to call it from outside of ring.Ring, can we rename the method to "reload" without the leading underscore?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-07-19 22:49:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-07-19 22:50:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This seems like the wrong way to fix this. If the ring is not auto-reloading under specific circumstances, it seems that should be fixed rather than patching the problem after the fact and exposing what was a private method that consumers of the ring didn't need to know about before."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-07-20 05:22:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The problem isn't actually in the ring, though. The problem is that the replicators don't do any ring operations after the ring is first loaded if there were no devices to start with. IMO, this is a problem with the ring client, not the ring itself.

An alternative would be to add a setter to .devs on the Ring class so that it checks the ring file every time .devs is accessed (subject to the config file frequency setting). Is that more in line with what you are thinking?

I'm fine with either way, with a slight bias towards fixing the replicators rather than adding the setter to the ring. But if you think the setter method is better, I can submit a new patch for that."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-07-20 05:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Yes, it sounds like self.devs is the "bug" in that its contents do not auto-reload like the other attributes of the ring. Seems like that'd be a good thing to fix so all can enjoy the benefits. :)'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-07-20 05:35:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Work In Progress

will be refactored based on other dev input'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-07-20 16:16:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
check for ring reload every time through the main loop

Updates object replicator and DB replicator to check for on-disk
ring updates every time through the run_forever() loop. This ensures
that the ring will be reloaded if replication is initially started with
no devices in the ring.

fixes LP#1026830

Change-Id: I36fd7be91aaa67abb7b72b09fe1da85f2cde0b01

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-20 09:30:41.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Attach ISO as separate disk if given proper instruction"

The following commit

  commit b63a3e8cbd8fe57d0be119368bf47964543270c2
  Author: Josh Kearney <josh@jk0.org>
  Date:   Fri Jul 13 15:57:54 2012 -0500

    Attach ISO as separate disk if given proper instruction.

    This gives the option to attach the ISO as a separate drive, like we do in
    XenServer, and boot from that instead of replacing the root drive.

    Fixes bug 914484.

    Change-Id: I0e0560f5fcbc361b60ff1284e7369997dd770fd9

Results in this XML config

  <devices>
    <disk type="file" device="cdrom">
      <driver type="qcow2" cache="none"/>
      <source file="instance-00000001/disk"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
    <disk type="file" device="cdrom">
      <driver type="qcow2" cache="none"/>
      <source file="instance-00000001/disk"/>
      <target bus="ide" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
   ...
  </devices>

which is broken in many ways

 - The same backing file is used in read/write mode on 2 disks
   which will cause data corruption on write.
 - The 'virtio' bus type does not allow device="cdrom" disks
 - The 'dev' attribute is given the same value on 2 disks

To compound the problems, the original commit completely lacks
any tests which would have caught the brokeness and/or identified
what was actually intended.

Change-Id: If1ec286f98fc91f9f411800bbb0adbf2797d2114
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Attach ISO as separate disk if given proper instruction"

The following commit

  commit b63a3e8cbd8fe57d0be119368bf47964543270c2
  Author: Josh Kearney <josh@jk0.org>
  Date:   Fri Jul 13 15:57:54 2012 -0500

    Attach ISO as separate disk if given proper instruction.

    This gives the option to attach the ISO as a separate drive, like we do in
    XenServer, and boot from that instead of replacing the root drive.

    Fixes bug 914484.

    Change-Id: I0e0560f5fcbc361b60ff1284e7369997dd770fd9

Results in this XML config

  <devices>
    <disk type="file" device="cdrom">
      <driver type="qcow2" cache="none"/>
      <source file="instance-00000001/disk"/>
      <target bus="virtio" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
    <disk type="file" device="cdrom">
      <driver type="qcow2" cache="none"/>
      <source file="instance-00000001/disk"/>
      <target bus="ide" dev="vda"/>
    </disk>
   ...
  </devices>

which is broken in many ways

 - The same backing file is used in read/write mode on 2 disks
   which will cause data corruption on write.
 - The 'virtio' bus type does not allow device="cdrom" disks
 - The 'dev' attribute is given the same value on 2 disks

To compound the problems, the original commit completely lacks
any tests which would have caught the brokeness and/or identified
what was actually intended.

Change-Id: If1ec286f98fc91f9f411800bbb0adbf2797d2114
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Return 413 status on over-quota in the native API.

Related to LP 1021373.

Previously, we returned a generic 500 Server Error on an over-quota
conditions, whereas this is arguably more appropriately reported
as a 413 status.

Change-Id: I5c1cdc9db54804c512d60e4179c1faa13516d6f9

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-18 20:48:10.000000000', 'message': "Fixes bug 1026307

Variable in for loop was 'instance_ref' in one part, but 'instance' in
except clause. Fixed.

Change-Id: Ic887d9078725ec9b676c4f49cf58b567759b6210
"}, {'created': '2012-07-19 20:07:38.000000000', 'message': "Fix error in error handler in instance_usage_audit task.

This fixes bug 1026307
In the periodic task that generates .exists notifications, if there is
an exception generating the notification for an instance, it attempts
to log the exception and continue. Alas, there is an error in the error
handler that clobbers the original error, preventing it from being logged.

Turns out a variable in for loop was 'instance_ref' in one part, but 'instance' in
except clause. Fixed.

Change-Id: Ic887d9078725ec9b676c4f49cf58b567759b6210
"}]
commit_message:
Fix error in error handler in instance_usage_audit task.

This fixes bug 1026307
In the periodic task that generates .exists notifications, if there is
an exception generating the notification for an instance, it attempts
to log the exception and continue. Alas, there is an error in the error
handler that clobbers the original error, preventing it from being logged.

Turns out a variable in for loop was 'instance_ref' in one part, but 'instance' in
except clause. Fixed.

Change-Id: Ic887d9078725ec9b676c4f49cf58b567759b6210

delete the underlying database row because the model delete

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat db : fix per-object delete

Fixes problem where per-resource destroy() operations do not
delete the underlying database row because the model delete
method is broken

Change-Id: I3562c9048f8d4e54c1ea51090e74abe982ffb330
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-07-14 16:58:09.000000000', 'message': "Use default qemu-img cluster size in libvirt connection driver

The recommended cluster size [1] for qcow2 is 64k, which is the default
when invoking 'qemu-img create ...'.  Remove the cluster_size option
from qemu-img invocation.

[1] http://www.mail-archive.com/openstack@lists.launchpad.net/msg11371.html

V2: Fix test.

Note: This patch is needed in the stable/essex branch too, otherwise it
is not possible to start Xen instances that use qcow2 images.  The old
qemu 0.10 in Xen cannot cope with cluster size > 64k.

Change-Id: Iafc290720a820cb5f57ded10a2f584fdc5cd5b49
(cherry picked from commit de5cb27e64267ec59e12a495a59880412cecb5e8)
"}]
commit_message:
Use default qemu-img cluster size in libvirt connection driver

The recommended cluster size [1] for qcow2 is 64k, which is the default
when invoking 'qemu-img create ...'.  Remove the cluster_size option
from qemu-img invocation.

[1] http://www.mail-archive.com/openstack@lists.launchpad.net/msg11371.html

V2: Fix test.

Note: This patch is needed in the stable/essex branch too, otherwise it
is not possible to start Xen instances that use qcow2 images.  The old
qemu 0.10 in Xen cannot cope with cluster size > 64k.

Change-Id: Iafc290720a820cb5f57ded10a2f584fdc5cd5b49
(cherry picked from commit de5cb27e64267ec59e12a495a59880412cecb5e8)

[{'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-07-11 16:04:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Mixing big code refactoring like this with a bug fix, makes it very hard to see what the actual bug fix is. Indeed, even after reading the bug report & the code diff, I'm still not entirely sure what you've actually fixed here.

Please re-submit this as 2 separate patches - the first which fixes the bug, with a clear illustration of the before & after XML that is generated in the commit message; the second which only does code refactoring."}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-07-11 16:09:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why does two patches make sense? So if I didn't report the bug but just refactor the code and happen to fix the bug that no one knows, you would have been fine?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-11 16:12:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Attach ISO as separate disk if given proper instruction.

This gives the option to attach the ISO as a separate drive, like we do in
XenServer, and boot from that instead of replacing the root drive.

Fixes bug 914484.

Change-Id: I0e0560f5fcbc361b60ff1284e7369997dd770fd9
