[{'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2012-07-09 18:12:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The line seems to be too long for PEP8."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-09 18:25:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/4181/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/155/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/5468/consoleFull : UNSTABLE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1665/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1678/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/7540/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-07-10 00:49:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Here is an alternative solution. The problem is libvirt_snapshots_directory uses instance_path for the path, and instance_path is set to ''.  The comment in test_virt_drivers says instances_path should be the current working directory.

$ git diff
diff --git a/nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py b/nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py
index e95d15a..8346167 100644
--- a/nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py
+++ b/nova/tests/test_virt_drivers.py
@@ -55,7 +55,7 @@ class _FakeDriverBackendTestCase(test.TestCase):
         # So that the _supports_direct_io does the test based
         # on the current working directory, instead of the
         # default instances_path which doesn't exist
-        self.flags(instances_path='')
+        self.flags(instances_path='./')
 
         # Put fakelibvirt in place
         if 'libvirt' in sys.modules:"}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-07-10 07:10:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The problem is not the instance_path, but the snapshot dir not being created. New patch ahead.'}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-07-10 07:11:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 07:28:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/4222/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-docs/188/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/5501/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/1698/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/1711/testReport : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/3018/testReport : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-07-10 17:58:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

libvirt_snapshots_directory defaults to '$instances_path/snapshots'.  And when instance_path is set to  the empty string.  This becomes '/snapshots' which doesn't exist.   While manually overriding libvirt_snapshots_directory works, the problem originates from setting instances_path to the empty string.



    cfg.StrOpt('libvirt_snapshots_directory',
               default='$instances_path/snapshots',
               help='Location where libvirt driver will store snapshots '
                    'before uploading them to image service'),
    ]"}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-07-12 06:51:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Even setting instance_path to './' the './snapshots' directory doesn't exist, by default. This will fix the tests. But we should discuss if we should create the dirs from configs at runtime (can be good but also dangerous: in this case, snapshots is in the root directory, and we can bloated it easily by mistake)"}, {'account_id': 24, 'date': '2012-07-12 12:52:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-07-13 18:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-07-13 18:31:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-07-13 22:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-13 22:15:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-07-13 22:15:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-13 22:33:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-09 18:06:55.000000000', 'message': "Fix snapshots tests failing
bug 1022670

When running snapshot test, FLAGS.instances_path is defined as '',
with snapshot_directory='/snapshots' which will fail to to permissions errors.

Making snapshot_directory=None, will use TMPDIR as base

Change-Id: I930e4f30ddffcf66c58312e92f0ae368e770e438
"}, {'created': '2012-07-10 07:11:00.000000000', 'message': "Fix snapshots tests failing
bug 1022670

When running snapshot test, FLAGS.instances_path is defined as '',
with snapshot_directory='/snapshots' which will fail to to permissions errors.

Modified class LibvirtConnTestCase to use libvirt_snapshots_directory=''

Change-Id: I930e4f30ddffcf66c58312e92f0ae368e770e438
"}]
commit_message:
Fix snapshots tests failing
bug 1022670

When running snapshot test, FLAGS.instances_path is defined as '',
with snapshot_directory='/snapshots' which will fail to to permissions errors.

Modified class LibvirtConnTestCase to use libvirt_snapshots_directory=''

Change-Id: I930e4f30ddffcf66c58312e92f0ae368e770e438

commit_message:
Extension to show usage of limited resources in /limits response.

This extension add information such as the total amount of ram being used by a
user to the /limits response in order to be used by the client/user.

Change-Id: Ia23c1858bda31cf28209d5a593774e53e79d8ccf

Happy for this to go in, but it will likely be short lived as cinder is almost ready. You should propose into cinder as well.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-14 20:10:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-14 21:47:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

A couple of minor questions. These questions apply to all instances, not just the ones I commented on."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-06-15 03:06:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The reason for putting the log message on a separate line from the log statement is because of the 80 column limit for source code. It's cleaner to save the message in a variable and reference that variable than to do weird wrapping across lines. Any decent compiler will optimize this to have the same effect as embedding the message in the log statement.

There is no point to creating more specific exceptions classes if they are going to be thrown to higher level code that doesn't understand driver-specific exception classes. The only reasons to subclass an exception class are to:
1) Add extra functionality in the exception class itself because you're doing something special (we don't need to do this)
2) Be able to distinguish different types of exceptions in a catch clause (this driver doesn't catch any exceptions, so there is no need to distinguish between different ones)

If you take a look at the rest of the code in nova-volume, I'm pretty sure it uses the same style for exceptions and log messages, because I merely followed the style of the existing code when I implemented the driver."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-15 08:10:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I don't agree with you on the local variables for messages front, but I don't want to argue about it either. Other parts of nova do the same thing, but they've been changing over time to include the string in the exception or whatever and just use line breaking.

If the code style is consistent with the rest of nova volumes, so be it."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-06-15 14:00:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Michael, can you point me to some exception code that uses the style you think is superior? My feeling about style is that it's more important to be consistent than to be perfect, and if there is an alternate style that's more prevalent I'm happy to use that."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-06-15 20:06:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(5 inline comments)

Avoid classic classes wherever possible…"}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-06-16 01:58:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Kevin, I will implement your suggestions next week when I return from vacation.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-06-16 22:03:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@bswartz -- you can see many examples of the style I am talking about in nova/nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py. It is true that both styles exist in the code base (in fact even in that one file), but I secretly dislike the temporary local variable one.

Like I said, I don't think this patch should be blocked because of that, I just would like to avoid adding next examples of local variables for no reason if possible."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-06-21 20:12:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Bumping this to keep it alive. I'm back from vacation and will be addressing comments soon."}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-06-28 17:16:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sadly I don't have any free timeslots to work on this for another 2 weeks so I'm bumping it again."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-06 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-07-06 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-07-06 17:26:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Restored

Bumping again -- I should get to this next week'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2012-07-13 21:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Please see instead:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9796/'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-13 21:22:32.000000000', 'message': 'Make timestamps available in Stack/Resource objects

Provide the creation time and last-updated time as attributes of Stack and
Resource objects so that external code does not need to access the database
in order to retrieve them. Use a Descriptor class so that the latest values
are always fetched from the database.

Change-Id: Ic3fa173b1dc8f2e5dc676a9152e8928ed2290913
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Make timestamps available in Stack/Resource objects

Provide the creation time and last-updated time as attributes of Stack and
Resource objects so that external code does not need to access the database
in order to retrieve them. Use a Descriptor class so that the latest values
are always fetched from the database.

Change-Id: Ic3fa173b1dc8f2e5dc676a9152e8928ed2290913
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
convert from connection_type to compute_driver

connection_type is deprecated for Folsom, now using compute_driver
to specify virt driver. This makes the change so that devstack
uses the prefered way.

Change-Id: I35c5ce64dc329121a61b888d44c05e3c70c6aecc

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-13 16:57:36.000000000', 'message': "Use explicit destination user in xenapi rsync call

Recent versions of xenserver use a newer, but buggy, version of rsync
that will attempt to parse out the username and fail if it isn't in
the destination. So, add it to the destination to ensure this works
with both older and newer versions of rsync.

Change-Id: I9b7f05a8ea5cf5b7fae1a55a2b8557b2bfe5b865
"}]
commit_message:
Use explicit destination user in xenapi rsync call

Recent versions of xenserver use a newer, but buggy, version of rsync
that will attempt to parse out the username and fail if it isn't in
the destination. So, add it to the destination to ensure this works
with both older and newer versions of rsync.

Change-Id: I9b7f05a8ea5cf5b7fae1a55a2b8557b2bfe5b865

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-09 14:50:49.000000000', 'message': 'Added 'always-enabled' submit button selector

In case when we do not want to disable
a form button after form submit, it can be
marked as <input class="always-enabled">.

Also fixed a bug in DataTable base template,
which renders <form> tags although there
are no actions to be submitted for that table,
which breaks the layout if a table is being
used for displaying data items without actions.

Fixed bug 1011527

Change-Id: I176844a3c69cdf260cb40a6574ae34b6a36ee2a0
'}, {'created': '2012-07-12 21:52:31.000000000', 'message': 'Added 'always-enabled' submit button selector

commit_message:
Added 'always-enabled' submit button selector

In case when we do not want to disable
a form button after form submit, it can be
marked as <input class="always-enabled">.

Fixes bug 1011527

Change-Id: I176844a3c69cdf260cb40a6574ae34b6a36ee2a0

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-13 16:15:18.000000000', 'message': "Sync importutils from openstack-common.

commit 8c74b37f5bdf1141b8c3724c8df460e6562d1985
Author: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
Date:   Tue Jun 19 17:08:35 2012 -0400

    Improve exception from importutils.import_class().

    The ImportError raised by import_class() attempted to tell you what the
    original error was by just doing str() on the original exception.
    Sometimes that's helpful, but sometimes a full traceback is needed.
    This patch includes a traceback for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I83b167baf99feacef1a3f91089b758c6cf9531d3
"}]
commit_message:
Sync importutils from openstack-common.

commit 8c74b37f5bdf1141b8c3724c8df460e6562d1985
Author: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>
Date:   Tue Jun 19 17:08:35 2012 -0400

    Improve exception from importutils.import_class().

    The ImportError raised by import_class() attempted to tell you what the
    original error was by just doing str() on the original exception.
    Sometimes that's helpful, but sometimes a full traceback is needed.
    This patch includes a traceback for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I83b167baf99feacef1a3f91089b758c6cf9531d3

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-12 20:10:42.000000000', 'message': "Change base rpc version to 1.0 in compute rpcapi.

A recent patch change the RPC_API_VERSION in compute/rpcapi.py to 1.1.
This change was the right thing to do in compute/manager.py, but not
compute/rpcapi.py.  This patch changes it back to 1.0, and changes the
code to only specify that 1.1 is required for the new method.

This version in the rpcapi modules is used as the default version to set
in a message.  The version sent in a message is the minimum version
required to be implemented on the manager side for the message to be
successfully processed.  For most messages, that is just 1.0.  In the
case of the new method, it's 1.1.

This patch also changes the name of his variable in the rpcapi modules
from RPC_API_VERSION to BASE_RPC_API_VERSION to help clarify this a bit
more.

Change-Id: I2bb4602845869bd44b39531eeb4f1e7c0c4c20c2
"}]
commit_message:
Change base rpc version to 1.0 in compute rpcapi.

A recent patch change the RPC_API_VERSION in compute/rpcapi.py to 1.1.
This change was the right thing to do in compute/manager.py, but not
compute/rpcapi.py.  This patch changes it back to 1.0, and changes the
code to only specify that 1.1 is required for the new method.

This version in the rpcapi modules is used as the default version to set
in a message.  The version sent in a message is the minimum version
required to be implemented on the manager side for the message to be
successfully processed.  For most messages, that is just 1.0.  In the
case of the new method, it's 1.1.

This patch also changes the name of his variable in the rpcapi modules
from RPC_API_VERSION to BASE_RPC_API_VERSION to help clarify this a bit
more.

Change-Id: I2bb4602845869bd44b39531eeb4f1e7c0c4c20c2

commit_message:
Setup PKI for Keystone

Required for http://wiki.openstack.org/PKI
specifically Delegation and Scaling section

when complete, you should see certificates and keys in
/etc/keystone/ssl

The important files are:

/etc/keystone/ssl/private/signing_key.pem
/etc/keystone/ssl/certs/ca.pem
/etc/keystone/ssl/certs/signing_cert.pem

Change-Id: Iece395413af767042235d6e1cc0421879a810044

commit_message:
associate_floating_ip an ip already in use

Fixes bug 10014860 to be compliant w/ AWS EC2 spec
instead of return exception.FloatingIpAssociated,
disassociate from old fixed_ip and associate to
new fixed_ip.

Change-Id: I54ab3492092940dbb01f2787cc329a0162698568

commit_message:
Remove VDI chain limit for snapshots.

Snapshots and migrations were coded with a simplifying assumption that
the maximum length of a VDI chain would be 3. Now that fast-cloning has
been added, this assumption no longer holds.

The goal of this patch is to remove the restriction for snapshots. A
follow-on patch will remove the restriction for migrations.

This patch changes the image-format for XenAPI images. Instead of naming
the VHDs, 'base', 'image', and 'snap', they are now numbered staring
with 0 as the leaf and going to N as the base-copy (root).

Old-style images are still supported.

Change-Id: Ieb073b42dc25db7cee4dfca7ff6525f7e7f46e8e

When retrieving a list with a lot of instances (thousands), a
significant part of the time is spent logging debug messages.
These messages don't provide much value anymore and just slow
things down unnecessarily.

Change-Id: I52cbec2b236bac587776c8a56e0f8dcae05294cf
"}]
commit_message:
Remove unnecessary logging from API

When retrieving a list with a lot of instances (thousands), a
significant part of the time is spent logging debug messages.
These messages don't provide much value anymore and just slow
things down unnecessarily.

Change-Id: I52cbec2b236bac587776c8a56e0f8dcae05294cf

Sync with latest setup.py from openstack-common which adds options
to SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG and SKIP_GENERATE_AUTHORS.

If you set SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG in your environment it will speed
up sdist creation by 10-20 seconds which also helps make tox run
faster (because it runs sdist).

Change-Id: I5da708d2e9547d5e554cf49ecfcf39591de6a4e5
'}]
commit_message:
Add SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG to setup.py.

Sync with latest setup.py from openstack-common which adds options
to SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG and SKIP_GENERATE_AUTHORS.

If you set SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG in your environment it will speed
up sdist creation by 10-20 seconds which also helps make tox run
faster (because it runs sdist).

Change-Id: I5da708d2e9547d5e554cf49ecfcf39591de6a4e5

commit_message:
Use setuptools-git for file inclusion.

Fixes bug 1002776. Let setuptools include everything we have in git for a
start.

Also, while in here, fixed up a couple of other setup related things.

Change-Id: Id5064e396f47375f23d499e188aa37a64a48c9f5

commit_message:
Prevent weird double ~'s in local versions.

The version generation code didn't account for developers running locally.
So while checking for the entry in meta/openstack/release that matches
the branch name works for release builds, it left an empty string in the
milestonever section of the version name. Instead, if we just poke the
branch name in there, local version string reporting should be prettier.

Change-Id: Iff7fdde78bf2ba60a1ab88b38ca2ea89260eb5c7

commit_message:
only mount guest image once when injecting files

Previously we could incur the costly guest mount operation twice,
if injecting files with any of net, ssh keys, password, metadata.
Instead now inject files in the same operation.

Also cleanup the internal injection functions a little
by removing the unused 'execute' parameter.

Partly mitigates the impact of bug 1013689.
Change-Id: Ib66d327e745593cf1e5897470750d609b2a58980

messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-07-12 19:45:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

At first I thought this was a duplicate of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9445, but looking closer, they seem to be caused by different problems, even if both are over quota errors.

I'm not a fan of using a 413 error since it makes it difficult to differentiate between the original intent of the error (the request body is too large) and the over quota error, but I see it's very common in nova already (and I'm guessing the API spec too)."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-12 20:21:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

commit_message:
When over quota for floating ips, return HTTPRequestEntityTooLarge.

Previously we were returning a generic Internal Server Error which seems dumb.

Fixes bug 1021721.

Change-Id: Ia30b8de22bcc00d159bb4894ab4dc5f4870c346b

Use common/setup based tarball version.

Updates to the latest openstack-common code.

Removes need for Final = True. Drive versions from git.

Change-Id: I156c09bd81f73312de30fd09aa9bca44e42c6cf6

[{'created': '2012-07-11 23:01:16.000000000', 'message': "ensure libguestfs mounts are cleaned up

Make a few attempts to umount the libguestfs
mounts, in case other processes are accessing
the mounts (like udev etc.)

If we still can't umount after 5 attempts
(with average delay of about 1s between each),
then initiate a lazy umount so that the mounts
might be automatically cleaned up at some stage.
We wait a further 10s after initiating the lazy
umount, before raising an exception.

Addresses the original issue in bug 1013689

Change-Id: Ib5ede9f705c833825a19308c140f99c5bf3a776f
"}]
commit_message:
ensure libguestfs mounts are cleaned up

Make a few attempts to umount the libguestfs
mounts, in case other processes are accessing
the mounts (like udev etc.)

If we still can't umount after 5 attempts
(with average delay of about 1s between each),
then initiate a lazy umount so that the mounts
might be automatically cleaned up at some stage.
We wait a further 10s after initiating the lazy
umount, before raising an exception.

Addresses the original issue in bug 1013689

Change-Id: Ib5ede9f705c833825a19308c140f99c5bf3a776f

commit_message:
Add --is-public to image-create

This moves image-create closer to image-update by adding
--is-public and hiding the help output of --public. The
--public option will be removed once devstack no longer
depends on it.

Fix bug 1023632

Change-Id: I2c58655ba56eef1fa486246618c4fb5bd3c6c8cf

commit_message:
Propagate setup.py change from common.

This pulls in the following patch:

commit 8a967b16dc2ffd60bc19bee09f45e665ddcc9a81
Author: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Date:   Mon Jul 2 17:19:06 2012 -0400

    Fix up openstack-common build.

    Ironically enough, even though the code to manage this is in
    openstack-common, openstack-common wasn't using it. This patch fixes doc
    generation, as well as setuptools-git integration and versioning.

Change-Id: Ibb2041b131c67aba963e2dd81dcdfd105e1f9b33

commit_message:
Add SKIP_GENERATE_AUTHORS option to setup.py

Updates the generate_authors function in setup.py so that
it will skip generation of the authors file if the
SKIP_GENERATE_AUTHORS env variable is set.

Authors doesn't currently take that long to generate but having
the option to explicitly skip it (regardless of whether .git is there)
seems like a good addition.

Change-Id: Ie18064d2450cecc86f18d0b10e1ce473253d1a51

subject: Admin Auth URI prefix
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 4, 'name': 'Dolph Mathews', 'email': 'dolph.mathews@gmail.com', 'username': 'dolph'}, {'_account_id': 6, 'name': 'Joe Heck', 'email': 'heckj@mac.com', 'username': 'heckj'}, {'_account_id': 894, 'name': 'Juan J. Martínez', 'email': 'jjm@usebox.net', 'username': 'jjmartinez'}, {'_account_id': 1955, 'name': 'Alan Pevec', 'email': 'alan.pevec@redhat.com', 'username': 'apevec'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2218, 'name': 'Adam Young', 'email': 'adam@younglogic.com', 'username': 'ayoung'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-05-05 19:00:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why add the prefix? In doing so, aren't you effectively changing the resource paths for the API such that if an implementor uses this configuration option, standard clients won't be able to work with it?"}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2012-05-07 14:45:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Why do we have auth_host/auth_port/auth_protocol parameters at all?
There should be only "auth_uri" parameter and other auth_* can be derived from it, now is a confusing mix:
auth_host/port/protocol are used in _get_http_connection even if they don't match auth_uri parameter.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-05-07 15:41:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

the auth_uri values is returned in the messages for 403 etc  to tell the client where to get authorized in the future.  From this perspective,  THe Keystone main admin uris are two different things.  THe first is used by clients to get tokens,  the second by services to validate them.

A shorter scheme would be
auth_uri
auth_admin_uri

but my addition of the prefix allows them to co-exist.

It does not break the existing client tools,  as shown by the fact that glance image-list works.'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2012-05-07 16:30:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

As discussed on IRC, let's get this in, it's no-op by default.
Then later refactor to use auth_uri and auth_admin_uri and deprecate auth_protocol/host/port parameters."}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-05-08 15:02:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

What about adding a commented entry in etc/keystone.conf.sample?

It makes me nervous adding configuration tokens that aren't documented anywhere."}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2012-05-09 09:31:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> What about adding a commented entry in etc/keystone.conf.sample?

keystone.conf.sample is for the server, this is middleware for which we don't have a sample config in the keystone project . It would need to be documented in paste.ini samples in each nova, glance.
Or sample generic auth_token paste-deploy section added in keystone, but this can be a separate change.

But otherwise, yes, all config options should be documented like in proposed keystone change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7088/"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-05-11 15:25:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

I'm good with this (it *shouldn't* break correctly written clients), but the merge is going to fail on PEP8."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2012-05-14 15:18:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2012-05-16 08:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Admin Auth URI prefix

Allows the prepending of a prefix to the URI used for admin tasks.  This allows URIs like
https://hostname/keystone/main/v2.0

PEP8 fix
Added To Unit test to ensure auth_prefix is checked

Bug: 994860
Change-Id: I851e059e8b17c1bc02ab93d8b09a3fb47b9d3fee

[{'created': '2012-07-13 15:01:46.000000000', 'message': 'Add SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG option to setup.py

Updates the write_git_changelog function in setup.py so that
it will skip changelog generation if the SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG
env variable is set.

The motivation for this change is to speed up running sdist which
gets executed at the begining of a tox run. Some projects (like Nova)
can take between 10-20 seconds to generate a changelog in this fashion.

Change-Id: I2e75060d303bc8fae784129e8e42f09922a8b09e
'}]
commit_message:
Add SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG option to setup.py

Updates the write_git_changelog function in setup.py so that
it will skip changelog generation if the SKIP_WRITE_GIT_CHANGELOG
env variable is set.

The motivation for this change is to speed up running sdist which
gets executed at the begining of a tox run. Some projects (like Nova)
can take between 10-20 seconds to generate a changelog in this fashion.

Change-Id: I2e75060d303bc8fae784129e8e42f09922a8b09e

commit_message:
Make get_endpoint a generic reusable function.

This patch refactors the get_endpoint function to make it more generic
and top level so that it can be more easily accessed and tested.

Adds service_type, endpoint_region, and endpoint_type options to
the get_endpoint function as well.

Added a new test suite specifically for get_endpoint.

The motivation for this change is that we'll need to be able to
parse the 'object-store' endpoint for each tenant in order to
enable multi-tenant storage in the swift storage backend.

Partially implements blueprint: swift-tenant-specific-storage

Change-Id: Icf773a1eb057fc9d65cf54890afa4638f2aee0b4

commit_message:
heat engine : fix create_stack response format

create_stack response is broken now the StackId formatting
is done in the API, modify response format to fix.

Change-Id: I013bdb5ed992ce735905225cc4415fc0cfc5ce92
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add option sql_max_retries for database connection.

Fixes bug 1019728

also add unit tests for linux bridge plugin config

Change-Id: Ibfea9bac87ba36f301671a35de81577debcd460e

"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-20 14:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So I've been testing this patch out and the use of a "master worker" process confuses me.

First, killing the parent (original) pid will leave all of the children still running, this is because the "master worker" is the only process that catches signals and stops it's children. 

Second, since the os module is no longer monkey patched, the call to join the "master worker" ends up blocking the original pid.

As a result, I don't see the point of the "master worker" process. It doesn't seem to add any value and only makes it harder to kill the service.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-20 16:52:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-06-20 16:56:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Answering Johannes' question... that is from Swift, where much of this code originates:

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/95786e577c328778de9a734bcd664dd7a7daf46b/swift/common/wsgi.py#L139

Should be able to remove that line.

Best,
-jay"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-21 19:04:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

Hi Johannes,
Thanks for actually trying out this patch and sorry for the confusion (of master_worker). Let me explain a little bit of why master_worker is needed: (could be TL;DR)
So Nova comes with several API services: EC2, OSAPI_compute, OSAPI_volume, Metadata. (All of them can benefit from being multiprocess.)  When multiprocess is enabled, user is able to decide which service(s) run in mulitprocess mode and # of workers, via configuring API_workers flag. 

Everything looks fine but there is this 'nova-api' application inside nova/bin, which would launch all enabled API services. Without this patch, all API services are basically green threads running in one process. With my patch, if one runs OSAPI_compute with 2 processes,  OSAPI_volume with 2 process and the rest without multiprocess, the parent (original) process has to record children's pid for different services, has to wait for different services children (which isn't possible since os isn't monkey patched). Adding a master_worker is my attempt to have better isolation on this and handle the case of running multiple API services with on application (nova-api): each service has their own master worker to handle signal, check children status. As a side effect, one is able to terminate one API service (by killing its master worker) without affecting other service. 

So your first concern is actually expected behaviour. And the join master worker block parent process can be fixed. I'll do that in next patch set.

Please let me know if you have any question/suggestion.  Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-21 19:12:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Btw, glance multiprocess patch doesn't have master_worker since glance-control put glance-registry and glance-api into different process in the first place.

Keystone is using similar way of Nova to launch public/admin service. So my patch to keystone has master worker too. (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/7017/)

Maybe fixing up nova-api/keystone-all to spawn enabled services into their own process can be an alternative to master_worker?"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-21 19:38:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I don't like the current design of this patch since it appears to have two conflicting goals: keeping nova-api multi-service, but then running services completely separately of nova-api.

For instance, if you kill the original parent process, then all of the services that have more than 0 workers will become orphaned and continue running.

This makes init script very difficult since it has to figure out what these other PIDs are to fully stop all of the services.

Either nova-api should be split into separate executables for each service, or we should pull the process management down into the lower layer so we don't have the problem of services becoming orphaned.

I'm leaning towards splitting each API service into a separate executable. I don't see the value in having all of the services run in one process and it complicates things quite a bit.

It's also simpler than trying to force process management down a layer."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-06-21 19:45:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

There are already separate workers for each service. The combined nova-api is just a convenience binary to run them all together. Volume-api is going away and metadata is most commonly run on its own so eventually nova-api will probably just be compute api again. For now, I would suggest that we change nova-api to run each service in its own process and skip the master_worker concept.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-21 20:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

So nova-api would effectively just fork off and manage children? A worker count of 0 would effectively be 1 then (when run under nova-api, presumably 0 would still mean no forking if run under nova-api-os-compute).

That seems like a reasonable alternative.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-25 17:47:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-25 17:59:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/3361/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/4757/consoleFull : SUCCESS
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python26/959/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-python27/967/consoleFull : FAILURE
- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/6097/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-25 18:06:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

There's dependency on this patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/8945/"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-06-26 21:46:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

While you've removed the master_worker variable, you still end up with 3 levels of processes, the original process, the multiprocess.Process processes and the children from that.

As a result, processes can still leak out since there's nothing to kill the children if the original process dies.

I took the opportunity to make some changes to your patch to implement what I think is a better cleaner solution. There are only two levels of processes (parent and children for all services) and it uses a pipe to ensure that the children die even if the parent is killed without having a chance to cleanup.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9033/"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-27 14:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-27 14:59:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

In patch set 8, modification has been made to handle the case when parent process has been killed/terminated. And about the 3 level process, I don't see it have any real issue."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 15:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed

- https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/6403/consoleFull : SUCCESS
"}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-06-27 18:38:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-06-27 18:55:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

superseeded by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/9033/'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-07-13 08:44:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Abandoned

This patch has been replaced.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-06-06 14:23:28.000000000', 'message': "blueprint <multi-process-api-service>

Add multiprocess support for API serivces (EC2/OSAPI_Compute/OSAPI_Volume/Metadata).

2012-06-6 v6:
    * Fixed process leak issue by putting self.running onto shared memory to make sure running state is sychronized between processes.
2012-06-1 v5:
    * Add unittest to cover worker recovery, service termination functionality
    in wsgi.py, fix python 2.6 compatibility issue.
    * Modify generate_uid() to introduce per-process seeds in utils.py to avoid
    collisions.
    * Add worker session to nova.conf.sample.
2012-04-28 v4:
    * Add SIGINT handler and fix child-parent race condition when Ctrl+C is
    pressed.
2012-03-30 v3:
    * Added metadata test.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: use the greenthread pool created for each process.
    * nova/service.py: remove debug code
2012-03-27 v2:
    * Fixed unittest error.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Use self._logger to do logging in multiprocess mode.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Move self._pool creation into proper place.
    * code style fix.
2012-03-25 v1:
    * Modification to nova/service.py and nova/wsgi.py in order to support
    multiprocess (a.k.a. workers) for various API services.  If multiprocess
    mode is enabled, (i.e. flags 'APINAME_workers' set to positive numbers),
    corresponding API service will run in target number of process(es). There
    is also a master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling
    signal/termination).
    * Add unittest for multiprocess API service, also alter testing/runner.py
    to adopt new unittest.

Change-Id: Icd8ee48ec7b6405af21c915fb95f89466750ffd4
"}, {'created': '2012-06-06 17:15:29.000000000', 'message': "blueprint <multi-process-api-service>

    * nova/service.py: remove debug code
2012-03-27 v2:
    * Fixed unittest error.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Use self._logger to do logging in multiprocess mode.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Move self._pool creation into proper place.
    * code style fix.
2012-03-25 v1:
    * Modification to nova/service.py and nova/wsgi.py in order to support
    multiprocess (a.k.a. workers) for various API services.  If multiprocess
    mode is enabled, (i.e. flags 'APINAME_workers' set to positive numbers),
    corresponding API service will run in target number of process(es). There
    is also a master_worker process spawned for managing all workers (handling
    signal/termination).
    * Add unittest for multiprocess API service, also alter testing/runner.py
    to adopt new unittest.

Change-Id: Icd8ee48ec7b6405af21c915fb95f89466750ffd4

commit_message:
blueprint multi-process-api-service

Add multiprocess support for API serivces (EC2/OSAPI_Compute/OSAPI_Volume/Metadata).

2012-06-27 v7:
    * Put API services into its own process (bin/nova-api, bin/nova-all).
    * Remove master_worker.
2012-06-11 v6:
    * Fixed process leak issue by putting self.running onto shared memory to
    make sure running state is sychronized between processes.
    * Add new unittest to check whether correct # of workers are started.
    * Fixed error found on Mac OS X.
2012-06-1 v5:
    * Add unittest to cover worker recovery, service termination functionality
    in wsgi.py, fix python 2.6 compatibility issue.
    * Modify generate_uid() to introduce per-process seeds in utils.py to avoid
    collisions.
    * Add worker session to nova.conf.sample.
2012-04-28 v4:
    * Add SIGINT handler and fix child-parent race condition when Ctrl+C is
    pressed.
2012-03-30 v3:
    * Added metadata test.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: use the greenthread pool created for each process.
    * nova/service.py: remove debug code
2012-03-27 v2:
    * Fixed unittest error.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Use self._logger to do logging in multiprocess mode.
    * nova/wsgi.py:Server: Move self._pool creation into proper place.
    * code style fix.
2012-03-25 v1:
    * Modification to nova/service.py and nova/wsgi.py in order to support
    multiprocess (a.k.a. workers) for various API services.  If multiprocess
    mode is enabled, (i.e. flags 'APINAME_workers' set to positive numbers),
    corresponding API service will run in target number of process(es).
    * Add unittest for multiprocess API service, also alter testing/runner.py
    to adopt new unittest.

Change-Id: Icd8ee48ec7b6405af21c915fb95f89466750ffd4

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-07-11 08:27:42.000000000', 'message': 'Convert remaining network API casts to calls

Change-Id: I5cdcc628293d3e7cf165c5ffe4883f138783f73f
'}, {'created': '2012-07-11 14:51:16.000000000', 'message': 'Fix for Bug 1021340 Race condition in network/deallocate_for_instance() leads to security issue

Convert remaining network API casts to calls

Change-Id: I5cdcc628293d3e7cf165c5ffe4883f138783f73f
'}, {'created': '2012-07-12 15:17:00.000000000', 'message': 'Convert remaining network API casts to calls

Fix for Bug 1021340

During compute/terminate_instance networking is de-allocated by a call to
network/api/deallocate_for_instance(), which is implemented as an rpc.cast to
the network manager. This in turn will eventually call
network/manager/deallocate_fixed_ip(), which in turn call the compute API to
trigger a security group refresh, which will get the instance from the database

However because original call to the network manager is a cast there is a chance
that the compute manager will delete the instance record in the DB before the
compute API (in the network manager) tries to retrieve the instance. At this
point the security group refresh fails (leaving rules in place which are a
security risk when the IP is reused), and potentially stopping otheraspects
of the network deallocation from completing.

Changing this from rpc.call to rpc.cast will fix this issue.

Aside from this specific use of a cast there are 4 other casts in the
network API:
  add_fixed_ip_to_instance
  remove_fixed_ip_from_instance
  add_network_to_project
  release_floating_ip

and to avoid other timing issues these will also be converted to calls.

Change-Id: I5cdcc628293d3e7cf165c5ffe4883f138783f73f
'}]
commit_message:
Convert remaining network API casts to calls

Fix for Bug 1021340

During compute/terminate_instance networking is de-allocated by a call to
network/api/deallocate_for_instance(), which is implemented as an rpc.cast to
the network manager. This in turn will eventually call
network/manager/deallocate_fixed_ip(), which in turn call the compute API to
trigger a security group refresh, which will get the instance from the database

However because original call to the network manager is a cast there is a chance
that the compute manager will delete the instance record in the DB before the
compute API (in the network manager) tries to retrieve the instance. At this
point the security group refresh fails (leaving rules in place which are a
security risk when the IP is reused), and potentially stopping otheraspects
of the network deallocation from completing.

Changing this from rpc.call to rpc.cast will fix this issue.

Aside from this specific use of a cast there are 4 other casts in the
network API:
  add_fixed_ip_to_instance
  remove_fixed_ip_from_instance
  add_network_to_project
  release_floating_ip

and to avoid other timing issues these will also be converted to calls.

Change-Id: I5cdcc628293d3e7cf165c5ffe4883f138783f73f

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-13 15:56:14.000000000', 'message': "LDAP Tenant Schema mapping

There are two issues with the TenantAPI for the ldap Identity.

There is a mistaken attribute_mapping entry, which was mapping 'description' into 'desc'. Per RFC 2256 there should be no need to map this as the attribute as it is already 'description' in the LDAP schema. I am not aware of any other schema that would use 'desc' attribute for a 'groupOfNames' object.

Since there is no support (yet) for users, tenants or roles to be enabled/disabled there needs to be a attribute_ignore set for the 'enabled' attribute.

Fixes Bug 980085

Change-Id: I03a77aeddcd61e352246667fa6516c325a6d9684
"}]
commit_message:
LDAP Tenant Schema mapping

There are two issues with the TenantAPI for the ldap Identity.

There is a mistaken attribute_mapping entry, which was mapping 'description' into 'desc'. Per RFC 2256 there should be no need to map this as the attribute as it is already 'description' in the LDAP schema. I am not aware of any other schema that would use 'desc' attribute for a 'groupOfNames' object.

Since there is no support (yet) for users, tenants or roles to be enabled/disabled there needs to be a attribute_ignore set for the 'enabled' attribute.

Fixes Bug 980085

Change-Id: I03a77aeddcd61e352246667fa6516c325a6d9684

commit_message:
fixes RHEL/Centos/etc keystone service name ref

In the keystone install documentation, a service restart is performed
the doc currently uses service keystone, whereas the service name
is actually openstack-keystone not keystone.

fixes bug 1023435

Change-Id: I2b1d01608da01e4f4b588d2a31af3475512319e2

commit_message:
More on fetching data from metadata server for Fedora images.

 * Added links RPMs for Fedora port of cloud-init
 * Added links to Yahoo's Openstack-Condense (Condenser)
 * Added a link to to EC2 docs on metadata service.

Patchset 2 fixes typos - metad and wtih plus fixes typo in README.rst.
Patchset 3 removes files I didn't mean to add, sitemap.xml and updates to .htaccess.
Patchset 4 really removes .htaccess. Really.

Change-Id: I5d1d33a2a63c2bfe93f82783f30879900498e4c0

> Looks we'll continue after failing to shutdown an instance. I think it's likely that other operations will fail after that, probably resulting in more than one exception being logged.
I'm not sure that is all that bad since this has the potential to be more tolerant of unexpected state of an instance, but it's a change at least.
Have you given it any thought?

The shutdown code just moved, I don't think it changed behavior. In other words, before and after the refactoring, shutdown failures were just ignored.

That said, just silently continuing is probably a bug, especially if a 'hard' shutdown failed. I'll add that to the heap of bugs I've noticed while combing through this code."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-07-06 22:24:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I misread the previous code, there is no change in behavior.

I'm not a big fan of hiding failures from the caller like that, but that's outside of the scope of this patch. At least it'll get logged."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-07-10 04:31:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

commit_message:
Adds snapshot_attached_here contextmanager.

This patch does three things:

    * Moves more code into vm_utils to better match our separation of
      concerns.

    * Reduces complexity of the vmops._destroy method.

    * Adds snapshot_attached_here contextmanager to make the
      snapshotting code a bit cleaner.

Change-Id: I544dc2ba203519d32a5ecce4a87157b5c4a55076
